# Why (share data)

## An ethical thing to do

>Whereas regulators of human subjects research often view data sharing solely in terms of potential risks to subjects, we argue that the **principles of human subject research require an analysis of both risks and benefits**...

-- @Brakewood2013-wj

## An ethical thing to do

>...such an analysis suggests that **researchers may have a positive duty to share data** in order to maximize the contribution that individual participants have made.

-- @Brakewood2013-wj

::: {.callout-important}
## Lesson learned

Plan your workflow in as much detail as you possibly can before you start.

:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-important}
## Lesson learned

Evaluate, revise, and update.

Document what you changed, when, and why.

:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {.callout-note}
## Recommended practice

Version your protocol.

*Manual is fine*: e.g, `nsf-2412345-protocol-2025-12-02v01.docx`.

*Automated is better*: Google Docs keeps version histories. [Quarto](https://quarto.org) enables git-versioned web sites as protocols.

:::
:::

## Good Enough Practices (Alaina)

1. Preserve Raw Data
2. Create a Central Hub
3. Use Meaningful Names

## Good Enough Practices

4. Preserve the Journey
5. Avoid Manual Manipulations
6. ‘Tidy’ Your Data
7. Metadata Magic

## Automate

- Script/code *everything* you possibly can
  - Learn R, Python, shell scripting
  - You can do it!
  


  
## Automate

- Capture data in electronic form
- Let the computer do tedious, repetitive, error-prone work
  
## Automate

- Multiple approaches
  - Pearce: Project-specific R packages
  - Pearce: Using [REDcap](https://project-redcap.org) to capture project metadata
  - Gilmore: Executable [Quarto](https://quarto.org) documents, see Bootcamp 2025 Workshops [I](https://penn-state-open-science.github.io/bootcamp-2025-quarto-I/) and [II](https://penn-state-open-science.github.io/bootcamp-2025-quarto-II/)
- Commonalities
  - Raw data live in secure place
  - Use API calls to gather, clean, process

# Where

## Big picture

- Privacy & permission
- Type(s) of data
- Repositories
- Data papers

## Privacy & permission

- Ask your participants
- Broad consent vs. narrow
- Store sharing permission & consider sharing it
- Pseudo-anonymizing
  - May or may not be required

## Type(s) of data

- Imaging data
- Non-identifiable
- Identifiable
